company.name: EMC Mortgage Corporation
company.business_description: EMC Mortgage Corporation is a mortgage servicer that acquires, services, and sells residential mortgage loans, and packages those loans into mortgage-backed securities. As of September 2007, EMC serviced over 475,000 mortgage loans with a total unpaid principal balance of approximately $80 billion.

case_info.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Fair Debt Collection Practices Act (FDCPA), 15 U.S.C. § 1692 et seq.; Fair Credit Reporting Act (FCRA), 15 U.S.C. § 1681 et seq.; Truth in Lending Act (TILA) Regulation Z, 12 C.F.R. § 226

complaint.factual_background: EMC Mortgage Corporation, a wholly owned subsidiary of Bear Stearns, serviced hundreds of thousands of residential mortgage loans while engaging in systematic unlawful practices. Defendants made inaccurate representations to borrowers about loan balances, fees, and delinquency status without first verifying the accuracy of loan data obtained from prior servicers. EMC charged borrowers unauthorized fees — including for property inspections, late fees, prepayment penalties, and loan modification fees — and collected amounts not permitted by the mortgage contract or by law. In addition, defendants harassed consumers with abusive collection calls, failed to disclose required debt collection notices, did not report consumer disputes to credit reporting agencies, and failed to provide required TILA disclosures when modification fees were capitalized into loan balances.

representations_made.description: Represented that consumers owe the specific amounts stated in defendants' communications, including fees and calculated balances
representations_made.quoted_text: 25. In the course and conduct of their loan servicing and collection, defendants in numerous instances have represented, expressly or by implication, that consumers owe the amounts specified in defendants' communications.

representations_made.description: Represented that fees assessed and collected by EMC were allowed under the mortgage contract and permitted by law
representations_made.quoted_text: 29. In the course and conduct oftheir loan servicing and collection, defendants in numerous instances have represented, expressly or by implication, that fees assessed and collected by EMC were (a) allowed under the mortgage contract and (b) permitted by law.

representations_made.description: Represented, expressly or by implication, that defendants possessed and relied on a reasonable basis substantiating their representations about consumers' loans
representations_made.quoted_text: 34. In the course and conduct oftheir loan servicing and collection, defendants in numerous instances have represented, expressly or by implication, that they possessed and relied on a reasonable basis substantiating their representations about consumers' loans.

counts.title: Misrepresentation of Amounts Owed
counts.representation: Defendants represented, expressly or by implication, that consumers owe the amounts specified in defendants' communications
counts.fact: In numerous instances consumers did not owe the amounts specified because fees were not allowed under the mortgage contract or permitted by law, and/or the amounts were assessed or calculated incorrectly
counts.conclusion: Defendants' representations as set forth in paragraph 25 are false or misleading and constitute deceptive acts or practices in violation of Section 5(a) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

counts.title: Unfair and Deceptive Assessment and Collection of Fees
counts.representation: Defendants represented, expressly or by implication, that fees assessed and collected by EMC were allowed under the mortgage contract and permitted by law
counts.fact: On numerous occasions the fees assessed and collected by EMC were not allowed under the mortgage contract or not permitted by law; nonetheless, EMC improperly assessed and collected these fees, causing substantial injury to consumers that was not reasonably avoidable
counts.conclusion: Defendants' acts or practices constitute unfair and deceptive acts or practices in or affecting commerce in violation of Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

counts.title: Deceptive Reasonable Basis Claims
counts.representation: Defendants represented, expressly or by implication, that they possessed and relied on a reasonable basis substantiating their representations about consumers' loans
counts.fact: In numerous instances defendants did not possess and rely on a reasonable basis substantiating their representations about consumers' loans
counts.conclusion: Defendants' representations as set forth in paragraph 34 are false or misleading and constitute deceptive acts or practices in violation of Section 5(a) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

counts.title: Harassment or Abuse (FDCPA § 806)
counts.representation: In connection with the collection of debts in default when obtained, defendants caused telephones to ring repeatedly with intent to annoy or harass, and placed calls without meaningful disclosure of the caller's identity
counts.fact: Such conduct — repeated/continuous calls to annoy or harass and calls without meaningful caller identity disclosure — violates Section 806(5) and 806(6) of the FDCPA, 15 U.S.C. §§ 1692d(5) and (6)
counts.conclusion: Defendants' conduct constitutes harassment or abuse in violation of Section 806 of the FDCPA, 15 U.S.C. § 1692d, and pursuant to Section 814, also constitutes unfair or deceptive acts or practices in violation of the FTC Act

counts.title: False or Misleading Representations (FDCPA § 807)
counts.representation: In connection with collection of debts in default when obtained, defendants falsely represented the character, amount, or legal status of debts; communicated false credit information including failure to disclose disputed status; used false or deceptive means to collect debts; and failed to disclose that they were attempting to collect a debt
counts.fact: These practices — misrepresenting debt amounts or status, withholding dispute information from credit bureaus, using deceptive collection means, and omitting required debt-collector disclosures — are prohibited by Sections 807(2)(A), (B), (8), (10), and (11) of the FDCPA
counts.conclusion: Defendants' acts and practices constitute false or misleading representations in violation of Section 807 of the FDCPA, 15 U.S.C. § 1692e, and pursuant to Section 814, also constitute unfair or deceptive acts or practices in violation of the FTC Act

counts.title: Unfair Practices — Unauthorized Collection Amounts (FDCPA § 808)
counts.representation: In connection with collection of debts in default when obtained, defendants collected amounts — including interest, fees, charges, or expenses — not authorized by the agreement creating the debt or permitted by law
counts.fact: Such collection of unauthorized amounts violates Section 808(1) of the FDCPA, 15 U.S.C. § 1692f(1), which prohibits unfair or unconscionable collection means including collecting amounts not authorized by the debt agreement or law
counts.conclusion: Defendants' acts and practices constitute unfair practices in violation of Section 808 of the FDCPA, 15 U.S.C. § 1692f, and pursuant to Section 814, also constitute unfair or deceptive acts or practices in violation of the FTC Act

counts.title: Failure to Validate Debts (FDCPA § 809)
counts.representation: In connection with collection of debts in default when obtained, defendants failed to notify consumers of their right to dispute and obtain verification of the debt and to obtain the name of the original creditor, either in the initial communication or within five days thereafter
counts.fact: Section 809(a) of the FDCPA, 15 U.S.C. § 1692g(a), requires debt collectors to provide consumers with written validation notice containing these rights in or within five days of the initial communication; defendants failed to do so
counts.conclusion: Defendants' acts and practices constitute a failure to validate debts in violation of Section 809(a) of the FDCPA, 15 U.S.C. § 1692g(a), and pursuant to Section 814, also constitute unfair or deceptive acts or practices in violation of the FTC Act

counts.title: Failure to Report Disputes to Consumer Reporting Agencies (FCRA § 623)
counts.representation: In numerous instances where consumers informed defendants that they disputed the completeness or accuracy of information furnished to consumer reporting agencies, defendants did not report those disputes to any or all of the consumer reporting agencies to which they furnished the information
counts.fact: Section 623(a)(3) of the FCRA, 15 U.S.C. § 1681s-2(a)(3), requires furnishers of information to notify consumer reporting agencies when a consumer disputes the information; defendants failed to comply with this requirement
counts.conclusion: Defendants' acts and practices constitute violations of Section 623(a)(3) of the FCRA, 15 U.S.C. § 1681s-2(a)(3), and pursuant to Section 621(a), also constitute unfair or deceptive acts or practices in violation of Section 5(a) of the FTC Act

counts.title: Failure to Provide Required TILA/Regulation Z Disclosures
counts.representation: In numerous instances, defendants included the cost of a modification fee (typically $500) in the unpaid principal balance of modified loans without providing required disclosures
counts.fact: Sections 226.18 and 226.20 of Regulation Z, 12 C.F.R. §§ 226.18 and 226.20, require creditors to provide new loan disclosures when a modification fee is capitalized into the principal balance creating a new transaction; defendants failed to provide these disclosures
counts.conclusion: Defendants' acts and practices constitute violations of Sections 226.18 and 226.20 of Regulation Z, and pursuant to Section 108(c) of the TILA, 15 U.S.C. § 1607(c), every such violation also constitutes a violation of the FTC Act

definitions.Bank: a bank that is exempt from the FTC's jurisdiction pursuant to Section 5(a)(2) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. §45(a)(2). "Bank" shall not include any person or entity controlled directly or indirectly by a bank and that is not itself a bank, such as an operating subsidiary or affiliate of a bank that is not itself a bank
definitions.Bear Stearns: The Bear Stearns Companies LLC, f/d/b/a The Bear Stearns Companies, Inc., a Delaware corporation, and its successors and assigns, by whatever names they might be known, but not including any bank
definitions.Clear and prominent: information is displayed in a manner that is readily noticeable, readable, and understandable
definitions.Competent and reliable evidence: tests, analyses, research, studies, or other evidence, including a data integrity program that complies with Section VII of this Order, based on the expertise of professionals in the relevant area, that has been conducted and evaluated in an objective manner by persons qualified to do so, using procedures generally accepted in the profession to yield accurate and reliable results
definitions.EMC: EMC Mortgage Corporation, a Delaware corporation, and its successors and assigns, by whatever names they might be known, but not including any bank
definitions.FCRA: the Fair Credit Reporting Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 1681–1681x, as amended
definitions.FDCPA: the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 1601–1692, as amended
definitions.FTC Act: the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 41–58, as amended
definitions.Fees: all fees, charges, and penalties, including but not limited to fees for late payments, property inspections, broker's price opinions, appraisals, legal services, reinstatement, modification, and any other fees or charges that a consumer is or was assessed by defendants or any other person in connection with the servicing of any loan
definitions.Loan: a residential mortgage loan, i.e., a loan secured by a lien on real property taken as security for the repayment of the loan
definitions.Loan instruments: the mortgage deed and/or promissory note signed by the consumer to consummate his or her loan
definitions.Person: any individual, group, unincorporated association, limited or general partnership, corporation, trust, or other business entity
definitions.Property inspection: an inspection of the property securing a loan to determine the property's physical condition and occupancy status
definitions.Servicing: receiving any payments from (or for) a consumer pursuant to the terms of any loan, including amounts for escrow accounts, and making the payments of principal and interest and such other payments with respect to the amounts received from (or for) the consumer as may be required pursuant to the terms of the loan. "Servicing" shall also include any related loan servicing activity such as the administration of loan accounts, sending periodic billing statements to a consumer, maintaining records of the status of the consumer's loan accounts, providing information to and resolving disputes with the consumer regarding loan accounts, the collection of loan payments, the foreclosure of real property, the use of consumer reports and the furnishing of information to consumer reporting agencies, and the collection or imposition of fees in relation to any of the foregoing
definitions.TILA: the Truth in Lending Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 1601–1666j, as amended, and its implementing Regulation Z, 12 C.F.R. §226, as amended

provisions.summary: For eight years after entry of the Order, defendants are enjoined from initiating a foreclosure action or assessing related fees until they have verified the consumer's material default, confirmed no prohibited acts have occurred (or have been remedied), and investigated any consumer disputes; defendants must maintain records documenting these steps.
